data.title: Palantir, Qualcomm Set To Report Earnings
data.description:
Get ahead of the market by subscribing to Seeking Alpha's Wall Street Week Ahead, a preview of key events scheduled for the coming week. The newsletter keeps you informed of the biggest stories set to make headlines, including upcoming IPOs, investor days, earnings reports, and conference presentations.

Wall Street opened higher on Friday, lifted by strong earnings from several tech companies. The upbeat results helped restore market sentiment after Thursday's decline, when lackluster reports from Meta and Microsoft left investors disappointed. "Indeed, just as the tech mood had soured yesterday, this morning that has mostly turned around following results from Apple and Amazon after the closing bell," Deutsche Bank's Jim Reid said. "This renewed momentum has helped sentiment after a more challenging day yesterday, despite the positive outcomes from the U.S.-China trade discussions. Investor concerns over AI-related capital expenditure resurfaced…," Reid added. On political news, the U.S. States reportedly cancelled a planned Budapest summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin following Russia's firm stance on hardline demands regarding Ukraine.

Amid a U.S. government shutdown, investors will keep a close eye on economic reports that will be released next week; however, government numbers are in doubt as the shutdown continues. The economic reports that are expected to be announced next week include reports on S&P Global Manufacturing PMI and ISM Manufacturing Prices on Monday, Redbook, and Atlanta Fed GDP on Tuesday. Reports on MBA Mortgage Applications and S&P Global Composite PMI will be released on Wednesday, along with Natural Gas Storage, Challenger Job Cuts, and the Fed's Balance Sheet on Thursday. Friday will see the release of reports on Michigan Consumer Sentiment, Consumer Credit, and Baker Hughes Rig Count.

Palantir (PLTR), AMD (AMD), Shopify (SHOP), Uber Technologies (UBER), Amgen (AMGN), Pfizer (PFE), McDonald's (MCD), Applovin (APP), Qualcomm (QCOM), Arm (ARM), DoorDash (DASH), AstraZeneca (AZN), ConocoPhillips (COP), and Airbnb (ABNB) will report earnings next week.

____________________________________________________________________

Earnings spotlight: Monday: Palantir, Realty Income (O), ON Semiconductor (ON), Clorox (CLX). See the full earnings calendar.

Earnings spotlight: Tuesday: AMD, Shopify, Uber Technologies, Amgen, Pfizer. See the full earnings calendar.

Earnings spotlight: Wednesday: McDonald's, Applovin, Qualcomm, Arm, DoorDash, and Fortinet (FTNT). See the full earnings calendar.

Earnings spotlight: Thursday: AstraZeneca, ConocoPhillips, Airbnb, Take-Two (TTWO), Block (XYZ). See the full earnings calendar.

Earnings spotlight: Friday: Constellation Energy (CEG), KKR & Co. (KKR), Enbridge (ENB), and Duke Energy (DUK). See the full earnings calendar.

Volatility watch: Circle Internet Group (CRCL) and Palantir (PLTR) are set up for a volatile week of trading based on options volume. The most overbought stocks per their 14-day relative strength index include Investview (OTCQB:INVU), Intensity Therapeutics (INTS), and Cambium Networks (CMBM). The most oversold stocks per their 14-day Relative Strength Index include FM Corp. (FMC), Fiserv (FI), and Stride (LRN).

IPO watch: Companies expected to price their IPOs and begin trading next week include Off The Hook (OTH) and BETA Technologies (BETA).

Dividend watch: Companies that have an ex-dividend date coming next week include Citigroup (C) and Ford (F).

Palantir Earnings Preview: Palantir Technologies is set to report third-quarter results next week, with investors watching for updates on its expanding AI partnerships and defense contracts after a strong run driven by demand from government and enterprise clients. Wall Street expects earnings of $0.17 per share (+70.0% Y/Y) on revenue of $1.09B, representing a 50.2% year-over-year increase. Palantir has been in focus as the firm deepens its push into defense and enterprise AI. The company recently teamed up with Boeing to provide AI tools for the planemaker's defense and space division.

Qualcomm Earnings Preview: Qualcomm is set to report fourth-quarter earnings next week, with analysts expecting the company to report earnings per share of $2.86 on revenue of $10.74B. Analysts have pointed to the recent entry of the company into the AI theme with its AI200 and AI250 chips and believe that capturing even a small share of the projected $500 billion AI accelerator market could add $10-$15 billion in revenues. If Qualcomm's AI initiative succeeds, significant upside is possible with limited downside risk.

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Alphabet: Rally Catches Up To Reality
data.description:
Investment Thesis

Since my last coverage, Alphabet (GOOG) (GOOGL) has surged 38%, strongly outperforming the broader index, and the current focus isn’t on the results; rather, it’s the trend, which the increasing pipeline at Google Cloud indicates businesses are committing to for the long term through the AI ecosystem it offers.

Its infrastructure demand still remains in excess of supply, which is an unprecedented situation for the company. With Alphabet’s full-stack AI solutions picking up momentum and their tie-ups strengthening, it’s well-positioned for the long-term growth trajectory from FY26 onwards.

$155 Billion Cloud Backlog Signals 30%+ Growth Through FY26

Google Cloud’s momentum increases with long-term visibility. The backlog came to 155 billion dollars during Q3 of FY25, up by 46% QoQ and an impressive 82% from the previous year. A major portion of the backlog comprises multi-year contracts for AI, thus validating the estimates of over 30% for the coming FY26 years. More than 70% of the customers are utilizing the AI solutions from Google, and Alphabet reported over one billion dollars in contracts within the current year compared to the past two years combined.

Alphabet’s full stack approach for AI, custom 7th-generation TPUs Ironwood, NVIDIA GB300 GPU instances, and Gemini models, are luring the best enterprise and AI lab clients, including nine of the top ten global AI labs. Finances are also reflecting the transformation, as cloud revenue jumped 34% over the last year to 15.2 billion dollars, the operating income increased by 85% to 3.6 billion dollars, and the margins are up at 23.7%. Larger contracts, an increased bottom line, and sustained demand for AI are propelling Alphabet’s cloud growth.

As per the CEO, Google Cloud has the widest chip options, which is attracting clients like HCA Healthcare and LG AI Research. 9 of the top 10 AI labs select Google Cloud’s platform. Revenue from gen-AI models grew over 200% YoY with ~150 clients processing ~1 trillion tokens each in the past 12 months for applications yielding efficiency gains like WPP's campaign efficiency improvement of 70%.

In the Q3 call, management pointed to a tight supply-demand environment that may continue into Q4-FY25 and FY26, with demand outstripping capacity even with accelerated server deployments and data center builds. This market element drives backlog expansion as enterprises lock in long-term access to scarce AI compute resources. Gemini Enterprise already surpassed 2 million subscribers across 700 companies that also have AI agents optimized for domains, boosting upselling. In Alphabet’s AI portfolio, diversification is seen in 13 product lines now exceeding a $1 billion annual run rate that is reducing dependence on core advertising.

The backlog's 82% YoY growth is in line with Cloud revenue acceleration to 34% YoY ($15.2 billion) based on that operating income jumping 85% to $3.6 billion and margin at 23.7%. This pattern indicates scalable economics as initial infrastructure investments yield recurring high-margin revenues. So, unlike spot-based cloud usage, that backlog provides top-line visibility for valuations.

As management projects continued AI-based demand with Anthropic planning access to up to 1 million TPUs, Alphabet stock may see value upside in upcoming years with CapEx expansion. For stock growth, this pattern supports multi-year compounding. As AI adoption enters production (via Vertex AI and packaged agents), backlog conversion can sustain 30%+ Cloud growth rates into FY26 and diversify Alphabet's revenue, as Cloud now ~15% of total which is up from prior quarters.

As operating margins are expanding with scale, it creates leverage. Each backlog dollar converts to improved profitability that will boost FCF post-CapEx peak. The $49 billion sequential backlog add tied to AI and signals high enterprise client engagement in Alphabet's moat that may continue to elevate valuations as Cloud's contribution rivals Search.

In a market where AI infrastructure scarcity continues, Alphabet may have outsized earnings growth that may derive stock appreciation through FY26 and in upcoming years as heavy CapEx depreciation normalizes and backlog monetization accelerates.

Google’s Valuation Finally Catches Up

Alphabet’s recent YTD price appreciation of 48% makes it trade close to its fair value, and the sector’s lofty multiples have risen in line with investor sentiment about the power of AI and cloud. Its current P/E ratio of 27x GAAP EPS represents a staggering 47% premium over the sector’s median level of approximately 19x and above its historical highs.

Therefore, GOOGL is no longer depressed; rather, the stock trades for successful execution and entrenched growth in the cloud segment above 30%. Other growth may rely on successful execution of new technologies within the income statement and successful conversion of the backlog into cash flows.

$93 Billion CapEx Jump Threatens Margin Stability Through FY26

Alphabet has an issue in its sharply rising CapEx guidance, which was increased to $91–$93 billion for FY25 (from $85 billion prior). As management is forecasting a significant increase in FY26, this escalation is primarily for technical infrastructure (60% servers, 40% data centers/networking). The CapEx is there to target and capture the expanding AI demand, but it introduces pressures on the P&L statement through accelerated depreciation and operational costs like energy.

These investments may continue to put pressure on depreciation growth, may accelerate in Q4 after a 41% YoY rise to $5.6 billion in Q3. This issue emerges from the core link between AI market demand-supply and financial mechanics. The massive Cloud backlog necessitates preemptive builds to deliver on and avoid losing enterprise deals.

In Q3, CapEx hit $24 billion, exceeding prior signals of $22.4 billion; this increment in CapEx over guidance reflects reactive scaling. For instance, server deployments and data center construction lag behind AI infrastructure demand, pointed out by the inability to fully meet client demand despite massive investments (as per the Q3 call). The CEO pointed to an aggressive demand for TPUs and GPUs, yet he also mentioned that supply constraints persist into FY26 and force higher upfront outlays without immediate topline offset.

Thus, the upcoming CapEx hike signals multi-year intensity, with FY26 guidance indicating elevation to capture AI demand across Cloud, Search, and YouTube. However, the related depreciation is a non-cash but is a margin-eroding expense. This links directly to the AI infra assets, Q3 other cost of revenues rose 16% YoY based on depreciation and energy.

Operating margin excluding a $3.5 billion EC fine was 33.9%, but ongoing CapEx acceleration risks can compress it further. Based on that, FCF at $24.5 billion in Q3 benefited from tax timing but faces headwinds. How? The trailing-12-month levered FCF margin lags (-27%) historical averages amid CapEx-to-sales at very high levels (469% over the sector median).

Therefore, this CapEx-margin issue creates a timing mismatch. In detail, backlog growth is at 46% QoQ and points to expanded future revenues, but CapEx is happening before the matching monetization and inflating costs now. As a result, Cloud's 23.7% margin expanded YoY but total operating income grew only 9% to $31.2 billion despite 16% topline growth. This operating leverage gap is partly due to AI infrastructure loads.

Here, management's framework for ROIC evaluation holds long-term bets, but near-term indicators like depreciation up $1.6 billion YoY point to dilution. Instead of optimizing existing capacity, Alphabet's full-stack AI pushes like Ironwood TPUs and GB300 instances demand bespoke scaling. So, this kind of scaling boosts energy/ops costs in upcoming quarters.

For stock price growth, this issue holds risks through FY26. The continued imbalances may lead to CapEx beyond guidance and, as a result, erode EPS via margin pressure. Q4 depreciation acceleration may cap the operating leverage despite revenue momentum. Whereas cash flow strain is seen in moderated headcount but offset by infrastructure spend limits, buybacks ($11.5 billion in Q3), or dividends. These points may elevate valuation multiples if growth perceptions land back to a neutral outlook.

The $8 billion CapEx guidance uplift ties directly to AI demand, but it is without supply relief. Thus, it risks overinvestment at high costs if enterprise AI adoption plateaus and competitors come up with better tech options. The street concerns about monetization stability for AI formats indirectly compound this. How? As infrastructure costs rise irrespective of ad economics, this can delay margin normalization post-FY26. This monetization delay may bring in volatility and downward pressure on stock multiples if depreciation outpaces backlog conversion rates.

Takeaway

Alphabet’s cloud powered by AI is not an interim boost; it’s an underlying transformation. With demand exceeding supply and the lock-in effect from businesses around the globe embracing their ecosystem, Google’s metamorphosis from an ad major to an infrastructure major in the arena of AI is an honest reality.

data.title: Deutsche Bank: Private Bank Segment Shows Strength In Q3 2025 Results
data.description:
Introduction

So far in 2025, Deutsche Bank (DB) has significantly outperformed the iShares MSCI Europe Financials ETF (EUFN), delivering a total return of about 116%, more than double the circa 49% gain for the broad European financials ETF:

While such significant gains have naturally reduced the potential future returns both for DB as well as the broader European financials sector, I believe the opportunities still outweigh the risks as far as DB is concerned. As discussed in my prior coverage of DB, appropriately titled "Deutsche Bank: Attractively Valued Ahead of The Investor Deep Dive", DB's current market value gives it little credit for anticipated increases in earnings per share in 2026-2028.

The bank's Q3 2025 results confirm the positive outlook, with a much-needed surge in Private Bank profitability hopefully the start of incremental profitability improvements in the bank's lowest efficiency segment. As such, I maintain my Buy rating on DB, driven by:

  • Robust capital position, allowing for additional share repurchases in 2026.
  • An attractive valuation relative to the broad European financials sector, as well as direct European banking competitors.
  • The potential for above-average EPS growth over the medium term, with upside to my €4.00/share EPS target for 2028 should equity markets stay at current levels.

In this article, I will expand on these points and discuss risks related to the investment case.

Company Overview

You can access all DB results on its website here. Deutsche Bank reports results in four key segments: Investment bank at 37% of Q3 2025 revenues, Private Bank at 30%, Corporate Bank at 23%, and Asset Management at 9%, with the remaining results booked in Corporate & Other:

Despite contributing only 30% of total revenues, the Private Bank accounts for 52% of all loans (primarily German Mortgages and Home Loans/Savings), followed by the Corporate Bank at 25% of all loans (primarily Corporate Treasury Services), and the Investment Bank at 23% of all DB loans:

At the upcoming Investor Deep Dive, I believe optimizing the Private Bank's loan allocation and efficiency will take center stage.

Net interest income accounted for only 49% of Q3 2025 net revenues, with net commission and fee income bringing in another 33%. The remainder was derived primarily from net gains/losses on financial assets, which is naturally a more volatile income component:

This revenue composition gives DB somewhat smaller exposure to changes in interest rates. Instead, the bank is more dependent on capital markets activity which drives Investment Bank/Asset Management performance.

Q3 2025 Result Highlights

With markets at all-time highs it is little surprise that Deutsche Bank is doing quite well. The bank reported EPS of €0.89/share in Q3 2025, up 9.9% Y/Y. Diluted shares outstanding were only down 1.3% Y/Y, hence the bulk of the improved performance was driven by better underlying profitability.

The return on tangible equity [ROTE] stood at 10.7%, up 0.5%. This was achieved partially thanks to lower credit costs of 0.35%, down 0.06% Y/Y. Provisions releases in the Corporate Bank and model updates in the Private Bank were positive contributors, only partially offset by higher provisions in the Investment Bank (due to commercial real estate exposure as discussed on the conference call).

From a segment perspective, ROTE marked the highest improvement in Asset Management (+9.2% to 28.1%) and Private Bank (+7.4% to 12.6%), with more moderate improvements in Corporate Bank (+2.9% to 16.2%) and Investment Bank (+1.7% to 10.7%) segments:

Loans were flat Q/Q, while deposits increased 2%. I think this is a positive development as it allows DB to be more aggressive on deposit pricing.

Private Bank and Asset Management net flows remained positive, with Asset Management assets under management reaching €1.05 trillion. The tangible book value stood at €30.17/share, up 2% Q/Q.

Segment Discussion

For me the strong performance in the Investment Bank and Asset Management segments was largely expected given the results coming out of U.S. peers in recent weeks (of course there is always the chance of one bank underperforming peers in a given quarter but this was clearly not the case with DB). As such, I believe the standout performance was the Private Bank which has been DB's lowest return segment for some time.

We observe that the Private Bank segment delivered 4% higher revenues and 9% lower expenses, benefiting from higher net interest income (net interest margin improved by 0.3% to 2.5%), as well as progress on workforce optimization with DB continuing to close physical offices. As such, adjusted costs were 9% lower Y/Y:

Even after recent improvements, the cost/income ratio stands at 68.2%, pointing to further room for improvement. As a reminder, when I first discussed the potential for a 12% ROTE as a new return target for Deutsche Bank, I highlighted that Commerzbank (OTCPK:CRZBF) is targeting a cost/income ratio of 54% for its German Private and Small-Business Customers /PSBC Germany/ segment.

For reference, the Investment Bank segment which delivered lower ROTE in the quarter due to elevated provisioning, shows a cost/income ratio of 57.2%, largely in line with Asset Management at 59%.

To conclude, further efficiency gains in the Private Bank, both in terms of costs as well as optimizing revenues by scaling back less profitable activities, will be key to DB reaching a higher profitability in the next few years.

Capital Position and Share Repurchases

Deutsche Bank ended Q3 2025 with a CET1 ratio of 14.5%, up 0.7% year-to-date. Outgoing CFO James Von Moltke noted that the bank should end 2025 with a CET1 ratio around 14% due to higher operational risk-weighted assets and the expiration of a transitional rule on the treatment of unrealized gains/losses.

The company noted that it would consider distributing excess capital above a CET1 ratio of 14%, which bodes well for incremental share buybacks in 2026. The current CET1 ratio already includes a €2.4 billion provision for 2026 distributions, of which €1.9 billion will likely go towards a dividend of €1.00/share.

Analyst consensus points to €6.5 billion in net income in 2025, or roughly €1.1 billion in Q4 2025 alone. Assuming a payout ratio of 50% and the €0.5 billion earmarked for share buybacks from 9M 2025 earnings, we observe that 2026 share buybacks are likely to be somewhat above €1 billion.

Valuation

I calculate DB should end 2025 with an EPS marginally ahead of the €2.91/share analyst consensus, with 2026 and 2027 estimates standing at €3.26/share and €3.71/share respectively.

If current equity market levels hold firm without a correction (which is far from certain given the prevailing bullish sentiment), I see upside potential to my previous €4.00/share 2028 EPS target, largely driven by higher fees in the Asset Management segment.

Even if we conservatively keep 2028 estimates unchanged, we observe that DB's P/E multiple of 10.6x 2025 earnings shrinks to 9.5x in 2026, 8.3x in 2027, and 7.7x in 2028.

For reference, European financials heald in the broad EUFN trade at roughly 12.4x their trailing earnings, while more niche ETFs such as the iShares Stoxx Europe 600 Banks (OTC:DJXSF) trade at roughly 10.8x their trailing earnings.

Hence we observe that DB is attractively priced both relative to the broad European financials sector, as well as its direct European bank peer group. Furthermore, I believe that while all companies are naturally trying to improve returns in the future, DB's low starting base, with a ROTE target of >10% in 2025, provides outsized room for profitability improvement.

All in all, I continue to belive that the opportunities outweigh the risks with DB, confirming my previous Buy rating on the shares.

Risks

As with any bank, the key risk in the investment case is a deep recession, which will weigh on credit quality and dampen business activity. With German fiscal stimulus expected to start in 2026, I see immediate recession risks as below average. Still, it is good to see DB entering 2026 with a forecast CET1 ratio of 14%, providing a cushion against unexpected losses.

I would add that DB's performance also remains dependent on strong capital markets activity, with the Investment Bank and Asset Management together accounting for roughly 46% of company revenues. I do expect returns to moderate substantially in 2026, although stubbornly high long-term interest rates should keep fixed income investments attractive, boosting the bank's key fixed income and currencies trading business.

The bank may also disappoint markets with a low profitability target, for instance targeting a ROTE of only 11% in 2028. Alternatively, an even higher ROTE target of 13% may be perceived quite positively. Taking into account profitability targets of peers, I reckon that a 13% target is somewhat more likely than a 11% ROTE target. I should caution that the higher the profitability target, the more likely it is to entail restructuring expenses, potentially pressuring earnings in 2026.

The ECB may still resort to incremental rate cuts, especially if its new staff economic projections, due to be released on December 18, 2025, shows the Central bank undershootnig its inflation target in 2026-2028. Discussions around phasing-in carbon trading schemes, which would have boosted 2027 inflation by around 0.3%, could tip the balance towards a rate cut. M3 Money supply growth remains very weak, at only 2.8% Y/Y in September 2025, pointing to a benign future inflation outlook.

Conclusion

Deutsche Bank's Investor Deep Dive on November 17, 2025 will hopefully mark a continuation of the strong progress achieved by the German lender over the past few years, admitedly from a very low starting point. Deutsche Bank's solid performance was driven by internal factors such as a focused management team, but also the fastest ECB rate hiking cycle in the history of the Euro, wild market swings and elevated volatility.

The next few years will likely bring challenges, with earnings in some years potentially falling well below rosy analyst projections. Still, my estimates show that a 12% 2028 ROTE remain attainable, with the opportunity of a 13% target arguably higher than a lackluster 11% ROTE aspiration.

DB remains attractively valued relative to the broad European financials sector, as well as its immediate European bank peer group. As such, I confirm my previous Buy rating on the shares.

Key risks in the investment case include a deep recession, weak capital markets activity, and the potential for incremental ECB rate cuts.

Thank you for reading.

data.title: Cipher Mining: 'Google Premium' Can Push Shares Higher
data.description:
Investment Thesis

If investors go through my recent coverage as of late, they will notice how the entire crypto mining space has become particularly interesting to me.

For the first time in many months, crypto miners have the clearest road ahead to accelerate the revenue growth profile based on the wide array of GPU infrastructure it has at its disposal. Over the last 12-18 months, hash rate growth has decelerated, and the Bitcoin price has hit a ceiling, but power/hardware costs have risen, making mining economics questionable.

But miners like Cipher Mining (CIFR) have realized the overflowing demand for AI HPC workloads offers a way for them to monetize their DC (data center) infrastructure assets and expand the growth trajectories beyond the hardening economics of crypto mining.

What Cipher Mining has going for itself is the intertwined relationships with itself and Alphabet that not only promise 2x revenue growth rates but also allow for secure pathways to fund its growth ramps towards those 2x growth rates.

We’ll get to hear from Cipher’s management this week with the Q3 ER coming up, and I suspect good things on the horizon. I recommend a buy rating on the company’s shares.

Recapping Cipher Mining’s Pivot To AI HPC Workloads

Cipher Mining ranks as one of the premium crypto mining companies and recently announced that they achieved their target of delivering hash rates of 23.6 EH/s of self-mining capacity per an official post earlier this month. Achieving these hash rates also means they rank as one of the top 10 crypto mining firms in the world (by hash rate), like some of their peers such as Iren (IREN) and Hive Digital (HIVE).

So far, the company’s revenue growth has rapidly decelerated, with the company’s revenues hitting a ceiling around the $153-158M mark on a TTM basis. Analysts are expecting Cipher Mining to report 4x and 2x growth in Q3 and Q4 of this year, implying full-year CY25 revenue growth of ~72% to revenues of $261M this year. If that happens, Cipher would deliver its first strong revenue growth since hitting a ceiling in 2024.

Unfortunately, with crypto mining rewards getting halved and Bitcoin prices staying stubbornly rangebound, Cipher’s management has looked towards higher asset utilization of its mining infrastructure by targeting tech companies facing capacity constraints in processing AI workloads.

That’s where Cipher’s intertwined deal with Alphabet’s Google Cloud and Fluidstack comes in.

Why Google Premium Will Drive Up Revenue Growth and Shares

In an announcement just over a month ago, Cipher Mining said that it signed a three-way partnership with Fluidstack and Alphabet’s Google.

Per the partnership, Cipher is expected to provide Fluidstack and Google 168 MW worth of DC resources via a 10-year deal that has the potential to deliver $3B in future revenues over the entirety of the contract. Google also retains two clauses to extend the contract by five years each per clause, which will add another $4B in future revenue.

As shown below, Cipher Mining has ~477 MW of energized/operational power capacity. 207 MW is operational at Odessa, TX, and 150 MW at Wink, TX, while the company also counts its JV investments at three 40 MW crypto mining centers under its operational capacity.

Currently, all of Cipher’s 477 MW of operational power capacity that is already online is being distributed towards mining workloads. Based on the agreement with Google/Fluidstack, Cipher intends to offer 168 MW of the 300 MW worth of capacity from its Barber Lake, TX, location to Google and is contracted to deliver this by October of next year. This delivery is a commitment set in stone, and Cipher, under no circumstances, cannot default on this commitment. In fact, Google has even taken a 5.4% stake in Cipher Mining as part of the deal. Further, Google has also agreed to backstop $1.4B in Fluidstack’s obligations to Cipher Mining as part of the deal, giving the crypto miner strong leverage to secure financing and fast track the development of the 168 MW data center that it has to deliver to Google/Fluidstack by next year.

This deal is very similar to the Google/Fluidstack deal with TeraWulf (WULF), as I explained last month. According to the deal’s economics, Cipher stands to benefit from $300M a year worth of revenues if one spreads out the $3B value of the deal over 10 years. (Note $3B is the minimum contract value as shown below).

Even if investors want to ignore the 10-year long-term revenue-generating horizon for Cipher, they can still see how Cipher stands to benefit from this deal over the next twelve months.

Granted that Cipher won't make bank yet on the deal until the 168 MW of DC resources is delivered. But Google is already committing ~$1.4B, half of the $3B, in future revenues if Cipher can deliver the 168 MW of resources. That does represent ~$140M in annual revenues and already gives Cipher a path of at least double the revenue growth rate, incrementally, after excluding the potential revenue growth from Cipher’s mining business.

There is a risk that Cipher defaults on the deal that I discuss below, but the risk/reward is hugely beneficial to the investor who gets to participate in Cipher’s revenue growth ahead.

Valuation Premiums Support Cipher’s AI Expansion

As stated earlier, consensus estimates peg Cipher to grow revenues by ~72% to revenues of $261M this year. Cipher currently trades at a market cap of $7.3B and records a cash position of $62.7M versus total debt & obligations worth $189.3M. Therefore, on an EV/forward sales basis, Cipher appears to be trading at ~28.2x CY25 revenues, growing 72%.

Markets are also projecting a similar growth rate next year of 68-70% growth. A majority of this growth is expected to continue to come from Bitcoin mining, but revenues from HPC workloads will start to trickle in by Q4 next year once Cipher delivers the 168 MW of DC resources to Google/Fluidstack, and I suspect CY26 revenue estimates will get revised higher to include some of the rent from the Google/Fluidstack partnership as we get more details over the next 12 months.

At the moment, we can assume that Cipher is expected to grow revenues by 68-70% next year, which actually implies a forward revenue multiple of ~24-25x CY26 revenues. Even if investors want to be conservative with the CY26 revenue multiple, they can assume a forward-looking revenue multiple of ~21-22x CY26 revenues. That’s approximately the same forward multiple. Cipher’s shares briefly topped out in September after the Google/Fluidstack partnership with Cipher was announced, as shown below.

Comparing the warranted revenue multiple of 21-22x CY26 revenues vs. the current CY26 revenue multiple of 16.5x implies an upside of 29% or a PT of $21.2 per share.

Risks & What To Look For In Next Week’s Q3 ER

Cipher could default on delivering the 168 MW of DC resources by October, and if it does so, Google & Fluidstack have the option of pulling out of the deal. This is not likely to happen in my opinion because when Cipher acquired the Barber Lake site in September last year, it was described as a site that features “front-of-the-meter capacity, a newly constructed, fully energized, high-to-mid voltage substation, and all necessary regulatory approvals.” In the same announcement, Cipher termed the site as “extremely rare” to find most of the resources and regulatory approvals in place that put management in pole position to deliver this site to Google/Fluidstack.

Cipher’s capital structure might be of concern to some investors since it has $62.7M in cash versus $189.3M in total debt & obligations. However, with ~$42.3M in EBITDA, the estimated gross leverage for Cipher turns out to be ~4.5x per my calculation. That is marginally elevated but still a lot more attractive than the 6.7x leverage that Fitch estimates for CoreWeave.

With earnings expected to be announced on Monday, November 3rd, here’s what investors can expect next week:

  • Q3 Expectations: 11 cents per share on revenues worth $76.52M, growing 217.5% y/y
  • Q4 and full-year CY25 expectations: 15 cents per share on revenues worth $94.5M, growing 124% y/y. For the full year, analysts expect 36 cents per share on revenues worth $261M, growing 72%.

Takeaway

Cipher Mining shares look interesting as it prepares to pivot towards AI HPC workloads, just like some of Cipher’s crypto mining peers. Google’s stake and interest in Cipher Mining’s pivot strengthen the transformation into a DC player for Cipher and firm up the latter’s position as it prepares to announce Q3 earnings next week.

I initiated my buy rating on Cipher.

data.title: Alphabet: Don't Chase Now, Even If You Missed The Ride
data.description:
Google: An AI Giant In Its Own Right

There's no stopping the Google AI train right now, it seems, as the stock of Alphabet (GOOGL) (GOOG) continues to outshine the market. Also, the market fervor has also helped it score remarkable gains recently over Meta Platforms (META) stock, as investors in the Mark Zuckerberg-led company probed whether the company's AI CapEx spend (toward AI superintelligence?) is still justified, given the lack of near-term monetization as compared with burgeoning growth and monetization engines such as the cloud computing business of Google.

Hence, the stunning reversal has likely caught more cautious Google investors off guard, especially those that quizzed about whether the search ads leader could struggle to compete against the onslaught linked to the AI first leaders like OpenAI (OPENAI). Yet, Google has proven that AI has always been part of its DNA, since the release of the seminal 2017 Transformer paper, that arguably laid the foundations of this AI revolution.

Hence, it makes little sense to think that Alphabet, under the capable leadership of CEO Sundar Pichai, hasn't mounted a full stack strategic framework to help it not only to survive fears of being disrupted, but also thrive against its archrivals. These growing capabilities arise from its holistic AI pillars, consisting of hardware, chips, to AI infrastructure, and a fast growing, multi-layered cloud computing business. As a result, I believe Google has clearly allayed the market's fears, while also propping up its capabilities to assert its dominance and influence among the other top contenders for the crown in the race to determine the AI race.

Back in my last GOOGL update, I expounded on my thesis about why I believe Google's antitrust case has definitively paved the way for a significant valuation re-rating, as Chrome was, after all, a critical underpinning of Google's strategy to diffuse its AI offerings. Yet, I didn't quite anticipate that the buyers have inverted extreme pessimism into the current optimism, as the volte-face has likely astounded even the most fervent of GOOGL bulls.

Now, it has become evident that not being compelled to divest Chrome from its properties has substantially strengthened Google's resolve to accelerate Gemini adoption across its ecosystem quickly. Note that the Gemini app now boasts an MAU of 650M, scaling quickly, and catching up with OpenAI's lead that Sam Altman and his team have painstakingly built since ChatGPT was launched publicly in late 2022. And, if we believe agentic AI commerce is going to be the next pivotal game changer for e-commerce, Google's stranglehold on AI browsers is expected to be decisive. And if we consider how quickly Google has caught up with the rest of its AI peers, I don't think there's an inch of doubt that Google could close in on OpenAI's dominance, as it's not just a search advertising company.

Google Cloud's Growth Momentum Has Strengthened

Google Cloud's renaissance, under the remarkable leadership of CEO Thomas Kurian, has also been nothing short of breathtaking, to say the least. That isn't to say that its cloud computing unit could supplant the top two hyperscalers right now; in Amazon (AMZN) Web Services and Microsoft (MSFT) Azure.

AMZN's ability to stay in front of the nascent race is aptly undergirded by its ability to monetize these capacity additions quickly, while also expected to build significant AI clusters that could run fully on its own custom chips. However, hasn't that been Google's strategy for some time already, when it comes to owning its own chip stack?

Recall that OpenAI was reportedly closing in on an arrangement with Google on their TPUs before Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang (NVDA) mustered a timely intervention that culminated in the announcement to invest $100B in OpenAI, as part of its multi-year build cadence. I believe Huang reckoned that keeping OpenAI well within Nvidia's orbit isn't merely strategic, but also fundamental to Nvidia's success.

Hence, it's going to be a very exciting battle royale for investors of AMZN and GOOGL, as both hyperscalers slog it out to supply Anthropic with much needed capacity. The argument in favor of Google likely corresponds to its well-established prowess in its tech stack, but the company still doesn't quite possess a similar scale when compared to AWS.

While AWS already boasts an operating margin of >35% over the past 12 months, Google Cloud's operating margin has just crossed the 20% level in the same period. Hence, I think the crux of the battle will likely depend on how quickly Amazon can convince the enterprise customers to stay firmly with the e-commerce behemoth. Yet, I think the future of custom AI compute deserves a hallowed space within the entire ecosystem, even if accord much respect to the clout based on the merchant chips of Nvidia and increasingly AMD (AMD).

Google: Navigating Lowered Profitability Could Ruffle Some Feathers

Nevertheless, it seems like the market hasn't been thrown off tangent with Google management's decision to lift its CapEx guidance in the face of more constructive opportunities.

Wall Street has also raised its 2025 CapEx estimates to the tune of >$91B, indicating an increase of almost 75% over the previous year. The growth cadence is expected to persist confidently into 2027, although we should expect a deceleration in the momentum subsequently.

Yet, these decisions could have significant ramifications on Google's assessed free cash flow profitability, attributed to a period of sustained CapEx ramp. Nonetheless, with GOOGL stock already being lifted to new highs, I think it's clear that the market has sized up its growing clout and prowess in AI.

The thesis of near term monetization in search has already been boosted, while the incredible growth profile for its cloud business is also undisputed, given the >30% growth in the past 12 months. While the market's confidence isn't a source of contention right now, we must also be circumspect when assessing GOOGL's thesis currently, as the stock is also no longer that cheap.

Note that while Cloud's contribution to Google's total operating profit has increased markedly, it still accounts for less than 10% of what the company generated from Google Services. Hence, I don't think we should completely eradicate the cyclical risks inherent to Google's ad-based business model, even as we contemplate the remarkable ascent linked to its cloud business.

Buy Or Sell GOOGL Stock?

As a matter of fact, GOOGL's forward EBITDA multiple of 16.4x has also surpassed well above its 10Y average of 12.8x. We can also glean the sharp valuation re-rating on the stock from the above chart over the past six months.

While I think that the stock's advance might not be impeded in the near term, investors who missed adding when it was still reasonably valued might want to hold back from allocating more right now. Such a dramatic rise has coincided with a substantive surge in its valuation, which I think may have been too fast and too furious. Waiting for the next pullback should help to digest some of the optimism and allow for a less risky accumulation opportunity.

Rating: Maintain Hold.

data.title: Buy The Dip: Bargain Dividend Stocks On Sale
data.description:
Co-authored with Hidden Opportunities

There is a very interesting element in human psychology. If Best Buy ran a 20% off exclusive promotion for the latest iPhone, it would gather significant interest, and people would rush to snatch the bargain. This is true for almost every consumer product out there. The entire premise of Black Friday was built upon the idea of discounting products to make large volume sales. The U.S. has the largest consumer market in the world – we like to be buyers of stuff, and a discount is a time to celebrate.

“We are going to be buyers of things over time. And if you’re going to be buyers of groceries over time, you like grocery prices to go down. If you’re going to be buying cars over time, you like car prices to go down” – Warren Buffett

While this urge to shop for bargains is true for consumer goods, it works the opposite when it comes to stocks. When it comes to money, people are fearful.

“Some people are more subject to fear. Bad news is an investor’s best friend. If you aren’t ready for your investments to drop 50%, you shouldn’t be in stocks at all” – Warren Buffett

At High Dividend Opportunities, we are income investors, focused on deriving a steady stream of passive income to support our lifestyle. When a quality income-producing security experiences a sell-off, we buy the dip to augment our income stream at cheaper prices. Let us now discuss two picks that have experienced a ~15% drop this year, amidst fears of lower energy prices and dropping interest rates.

Pick #1: ET – Yield 7.9%

With energy prices plunging, the midstream sector is being thrown out with the bathwater, even though this sector largely enjoys fee-based revenues, insulating them from commodity price swings. This makes quality midstream companies defensive investments in a sell-off, for investors focused on steady distributions backed by predictable cash flows.

The EIA (Energy Information Administration) report from Oct. 24 continues to show rising weekly U.S. crude oil production to 13.635 million barrels per day. The average weekly oil production in the U.S. is at all-time high levels. Produced energy commodities need to be processed, stored, and transported to refineries and end export terminals. Midstream companies operate the infrastructure for storage, processing, and other functions, including the vital arteries for secure and cost-effective distribution, while earning fees under take-or-pay or minimum-volume commitments.

Energy Transfer LP (ET) is one of the largest midstream companies in North America, operating more than 140,000 miles of pipeline. The company’s operations also include transportation, terminalling services, storage, fractionation services, and LNG regasification. In addition, ET also maintains 100% ownership in Lake Charles LNG, Sunoco (SUN), and 39.4% ownership in USA Compression Partners (USAC). This provides the company with multiple stable revenue streams and supports consistent cash flow for shareholders.

Note: ET is a Master Limited Partnership that issues a Schedule K-1 to investors.

During the second quarter, ET reported record volumes in gathering, crude oil, and NGL transportation, and the company commissioned its Lenorah II and Badger processing plants in the Permian Basin. ET reported a solid pipeline of projects, with several coming into service in the next 6-12 months.

This positions ET well for rising cash flows backed by multi-year contracts. Notably, 86% of the growth capital's spend ($5 billion projected for 2025) is going to be in midstream operations, NGL and refined products, and interstate natural gas transportation.

With a vast geographic footprint and connections to more than 185 natural-gas-powered plants, ET is in a unique position to work at scale with companies seeking reliable energy for data center projects. The company has reported requests to connect more than 200 data centers and more than 60 power plants in its operating region, making it a beneficiary of the AI boom with long-term fee-based contracts.

In July, ET made a modest raise to its quarterly distribution to $0.33, which calculates to a 7.9% yield. During Q2, the partnership reported $3.89 billion in adjusted EBITDA, and $1.96 billion in distributable cash flow, out of which they distributed ~$1.5 billion to shareholders. Management expects to maintain a 3-5% annual distribution growth rate, and with significant insider ownership of ~10%, the interests of the management team align closely with those of its shareholders.

When it comes to the balance sheet, ET lags behind industry leaders due to its higher 4-4.5x leverage forecast for 2026. Nevertheless, the company’s ~8% yield backed by recurring fee-based earnings makes it more tempting amid the midstream selloff.

Pick #2: SLRC – Yield 10.8%

Every few weeks, we hear commitments and announcements from leading global corporations to invest billions in the U.S. to build manufacturing and research facilities. Expansion of such facilities requires partnerships with thousands of local suppliers and partners, which often tend to be small or mid-sized companies. Ramping up operations to bid for contracts or expand scale requires a large amount of capital. The Equipment Leasing & Finance Foundation estimates higher capex demand and greater access to capital to fund equipment purchases in the coming months. Equipment financing is a $1.3 trillion industry and is set to grow as the U.S. continues to prioritize domestic industrial and manufacturing activity. Similarly, the Asset-Based Lending market, valued at more than $800 billion, is also set to see growth as companies seek flexible financing, backed by accounts receivable and other assets such as patents and intellectual property.

SLR Capital Corporation (SLRC) is a unique business development company that maintains a highly diversified portfolio of senior secured loans, largely tied to ABL and Equipment Financing. Combined, these specialty financing categories represent ~75% of the BDC’s investment mix.

Based on the company's Q2 report, first-lien senior secured loans represent ~96% of the BDC’s portfolio, placing the company at the highest priority in the repayment hierarchy, enhancing the likelihood of a full recovery of principal lent. Amidst tariff and inflationary pressures, mission-critical assets, especially equipment, tend to retain their value, making them excellent collateral to underwrite against.

At the end of Q2, SLRC’s portfolio comprised loans made to 940 unique issuers across 110 industries, with its average exposure at just $3.5 million (0.1%) per issuer. The BDC reported record ABL originations during the second quarter, and we expect this trend to continue in the Q3 performance. Net portfolio activity (originations minus repayments) in the ABL segment was $225.6 million, followed by Life Science Financing at $27.8 million. Equipment financing and Sponsor financing saw greater repayments than originations, but the former had $141.2 million in originations, the majority associated with leases tied to investment-grade corporate borrowers. SLRC ended Q2 with just one investment in non-accrual status, representing 0.3% of the BDC’s portfolio at fair value, immunizing the company's financials from the broader fears of credit deterioration.

SLRC began Q2 with its leverage at 1.04x, while ending the quarter at 1.17x. This boosted leverage was instrumental in supporting the record originations ($567 million of new investments), which management noted as largely closed towards the end of the second quarter. With $387 million in repayments, SLRC reported net portfolio growth of $180 million during the quarter, and many new loans that hadn’t begun making payments yet. As such, the BDC’s NII came in at $0.40/share for Q2, shy of its $0.41/share dividend, but the outlook is strong for stable dividend coverage. SLRC maintains more than $600 million in liquidity available for deployment, and is well positioned to participate in the upcoming surge in domestic projects as interest rates continue to drop.

Conclusion

Markets are going to move up and down. That is inherently how financial institutions are designed to operate. There are buyers and sellers, and negative news often triggers the seller in most of us more than the buyer.

At High Dividend Opportunities, we specialize in turning market fear into opportunities for passive income. When on sale, we buy fundamentally sound companies with recurring cash flows. ET and SLRC are just two examples of investments that are paying us handsomely to stay patient while others react emotionally. We don’t trade in fear; we collect income through it and reinvest to buy more. Turning volatility into opportunity – this is the beauty of our Income Method!

2025 Review

September will not be a month to remember for the Dividend Aristocrats. The ProShares S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats ETF (NOBL) finished the month with a loss of 1.68%. Meanwhile, the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY) posted a very nice gain of 3.56%, increasing its lead year-to-date. Thus far, October is shaping up better for the Aristocrats with NOBL up 1.63% through 10/29 and SPY up 2.77%.

Year-to-date SPY is outperforming NOBL by quite a wide margin, +17.8% versus +6.27%.

The individual Dividend Aristocrat performances in 2025 range wildly, with a handful of the constituents seeing double-digit gains and a handful experiencing double-digit losses.

Best Dividend Aristocrats in 2025

Dividend Growth

A.O. Smith (AOS) increased its dividend rate from $0.34 to $0.36, a 5.88% increase. The new rate takes effect in Q4 and translates to 6.15% dividend growth for the stock in calendar year 2025. For context, in 2024, AOS increased its dividend at a rate of 6.56%.

Brown & Brown (BRO) increased its dividend rate from $0.15 to $0.165, a 10% increase. The new rate takes effect in Q4 and translates to 13.89% dividend growth for the stock in calendar year 2025. For context, in 2024 BRO increased its dividend at a rate of 13.68%.

McDonalds (MCD) increased its dividend rate from $1.77 to $1.86, a 5.08% increase. The new rate takes effect in Q4 and translates to 5.75% dividend growth for the stock in calendar year 2025. For context, in 2024, MCD increased its dividend at a rate of 8.83%.

Currently, the average dividend growth rate for the Aristocrats in 2025 stands at 5.27%. With 12 more dividend increases expected this year, and likely even more since Realty Income (O) has historically raised its dividend rate each quarter, the Aristocrats are very close to delivering higher dividend growth in 2025 compared to 2024, when the growth rate was 5.78%. It will come down to the wire but my guess would is that dividend growth in 2025 will not exceed the prior year.
