data.title: SMHX: VanEck's Fabless Semiconductor ETF Could Be A Core Long-Term Tech Holding
data.description:
I have to admit to being somewhat skeptical when, in August of last year, VanEck's new Fabless Semiconductor ETF (SMHX) began trading after the great success of its sister fund, the sector bellwether VanEck Semiconductor ETF (SMH). After all, or so I thought, would there be that big of a difference between the two? Well, the big difference between the two has come in the form of the sector-leading performance the SMHX ETF has generated over the past year (see chart below). As you know, fabless semiconductor companies operate an asset-light business in that they design & sell semiconductor chips but outsource the semiconductor fabrication to companies that have the expertise to operate the complex & capital-intensive foundries that actually produce the chips. That being the case, the fabless business model certainly has some distinct advantages.

After completing my analysis (see below), I have come to the conclusion that the SMHX ETF is a BUY and should be considered as a core long-term technology holding in an otherwise well-diversified portfolio.

As you can see in the graphic above, the SMHX ETF has not only outperformed its sister fund SMH by a significant margin over the past year (by 7.6%), but has even more significantly outperformed the Fidelity Select Semiconductor ETF (FSELX) and the broad Philadelphia Semiconductor sector (SOX).

Investment Thesis

There is no doubt that global semiconductor sales are on fire:

As you can see from the graphic above, global semiconductor sales in August were $64.9 billion and were +21.7% yoy and were +4.4% as compared to the July 2025 total of $62.1 billion.

Now, the foundry model enables fabless semiconductor companies to focus on chip architecture and cutting-edge circuit design without incurring the significant cap-ex and risks associated with operating leading-edge fabrication facilities. By partnering with semiconductor foundries, fabless semiconductor companies can gain access to leading-edge design nodes without the hassle of & costs associated with in-house logistics and production.

The fabless semiconductor/foundry partnership model has been a grand success over the past few decades to the great benefit of the entire semiconductor industry because it enables all companies involved to focus on what they do best. That being the case, fabless semiconductor companies have two succinct advantages: cost-efficiency & flexibility.

However, the "flexibility" factor has arguably shrunk dramatically over the past few years because one company (Taiwan Semiconductor) has come to absolutely dominate the high-performance leading-edge of semiconductor manufacturing technology that is critical when it comes to delivering the high-speed, low-power technology required for today's AI processors and high-speed networking equipment.

Obviously, a fabless semiconductor ETF like SMHX will not give investors exposure to some of the leading foundries like Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM), GlobalFoundries (GFS), Micron Technology (MU), SK Hynix (OTCPK:HXSCF), and Intel (INTC) - among others. Indeed, the lack of TSMC in the portfolio was the primary factor that I did not invest in SMHX when it first came out, and instead chose to simply add to my existing full-position in the SMH ETF. In hindsight, that was an error on my part.

With that as background, let's take a closer look at the SMHX ETF, starting with the portfolio.

Top 10 Holdings

The top 10 holdings in the SMHX ETF are shown below and were taken directly from the VanEck SMHX ETF webpage, where you can find more detailed information on the fund:

As you can see from the graphic, the top three holdings - which in aggregate equate to 41% of the entire portfolio - are composed of the three leading providers of AI compute engines: NVIDIA (NVDA), Broadcom (AVGO), and AMD (AMD). I am sure you are very familiar with these names, as they are covered by the mainstream financial press and ad infinitum on Seeking Alpha. That being the case, I won't discuss them individually other than to direct you to my recent Seeking Alpha articles "Broadcom: The 'Secret Sauce' Behind Its Booming XPU Business" and "Chip-Rip Showdown: AMD Vs. Broadcom" and to show the outsized total returns these three companies have delivered over the past year as compared to the broad market averages as represented by the (DIA), (VOO), and (QQQ) ETFs:

The other observation here is that since the fabless semiconductor ETF has only 23 holdings versus 26 holdings in the SMH ETF, the percentage allocation in its top-3 holdings is greater (~6% more) than the same three companies have in the SMH ETF because sandwiched between them in the SMH ETF is TSMC:

Below the top 3 holdings, the portfolios of these two ETFs are quite different. For instance, the number 4 & 5 holdings of the SMHX ETF are Rambus (RMBS) and Marvell Technology (MRVL) with weights of 5.4% and 5.2%, respectively. Neither of these two stocks is even in the top-10 holdings of the SMH ETF.

Rambus specializes in designing and licensing silicon IP and interfaces to DDR (double data rate) memory chips. A slide from the company's Q3 presentation shows how RMBS has been able to draft behind the AI data center boom to significantly increase its cash generation over the past year:

As a result, RMBS stock is +118% over the past 12 months.

Marvell Technology provides a diverse set of data infrastructure semiconductor solutions spanning from the data center core processor to the network edge, including compute, Ethernet connectivity, switches, storage products, and peripheral interfaces:

Unfortunately for Marvell, many of its products compete directly with Broadcom, which is generally considered to be the global leader in high-speed networking and also in its XPU compute business with the hyperscalers. That is likely the primary reason that MRVL stock has been a relative laggard over the past year:

That said, Marvell does supply compute engines to both Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT), so all things being equal, one would have thought the stock would have performed much better than it has. However, earlier this month, Seeking Alpha reported that analyst Joshua Buchalter at TD Cowen downgraded MRVL from Buy to Hold and reduced its price target by $5 to $85, saying:

We downgrade Marvell to Hold as low custom XPU visibility makes it difficult for us to underwrite Street F2027 datacenter estimates. Combined with growing competition in Marvell's leading electro-optics franchise, we lower our estimates slightly. We think risk/reward is balanced after the ~30% run the last month. An AI beneficiary with strong IP, but we see cleaner stories elsewhere."

That "cleaner story" could well be Broadcom, which is likely eating Marvell's hyperscaler launch.

[LATE BREAKING NEWS UPDATE]: Amazon (AMZN) released its Q3 earnings after the bell on Thursday and said:

Saw continued strong adoption of Trainium2, its custom AI chip, which is fully subscribed and a multi-billion-dollar business that grew 150% quarter over quarter.

and

Launched Project Rainier, a massive AI compute cluster containing nearly 500,000 Trainium2 chips, to build and deploy Anthropic’s leading Claude AI models.

Marvell stock is certainly responding to this bullish development in today's trading:

MRVL: $93.48 +$4.91 (+5.54%) 3:41 PM 10/31/25

Regardless, another significant difference between SMHX and its sister fund SMH is that its top-10 holdings include the two largest semiconductor engineering design automation ("EDA") companies: Synopsys (SNPS) & Cadence (CDNS), the #8 and #9 holdings, respectively, which have an aggregate weight of 8.95%. In the SMH ETF, these two holdings combine for only a 5.14% weight. Both EDA companies became embroiled in the tariff/security war going on between the United States and China and at one point had restrictions on sales to China. Synopsys' restrictions, which were subsequently lifted in July.

Cadence agreed to plead guilty and pay $140 million to resolve U.S. Justice Department charges that it sold chip-design software to a Chinese military university thought to be involved in performing nuclear simulations. Synopsys stock is -17.8% over the past year yet still trades at a relatively lofty forward P/E=35.5x. Cadence has fared much better and is +15.2% over the past twelve months and has a forward P/E of a whopping 48.4x. On Monday, Cadence released strong Q3 earnings (a beat on both the top & bottom lines) and lifted its FY25 outlook to 14% revenue growth and 18% EPS growth while reporting a record $7 billion backlog - all of these results were driven by the AI data center boom.

Performance

As mentioned earlier, the SMHX ETF doesn't have a long-term performance track record since its inception date was on 8/24/2024. That said, the timing could not have been better, and the performance of the ETF so far has been exceptional and better than its sister fund SMH and the broad semiconductor sector as well, which are represented in the chart below by the Fidelity Select Semiconductor Portfolio (FSELX), the iShares Semiconductor ETF (SOXX), and the Invesco PHLX Semiconductor ETF (SOXQ):

Basic ETF Metrics

As I do with all my Seeking Alpha articles on ETFs, here are some of the basic ETF metrics any investor might consider before allocating any capital to the SMHX fund:

  • Expense ratio: 0.35%
  • AUM: 170.8 million
  • # of holdings: 23
  • 12-month yield: 0.03%
  • TTM P/E = 46.7x

SMHX has the same expense ratio as its sister fund SMH, which is on the high side and more than I typically like to pay for an ETF. However, you can't argue with the returns, so I put up with it (on SMH, I don't yet own SMHX but am considering a stake in the fund).

As you can see from the assets-under-management, SMHX is still a relatively small fund (in comparison, SMH has $37.1 billion in assets). That's a double-edged sword in my opinion: if there's a big market sell-off, there could be liquidity issues if investors all rush for the door at the same time. On the other hand, if money were to move into the fund in significant volume, it could result in concentrated buying in the fund's small number of holdings that might actually be a bullish factor. Meantime, as you can see from the TTM P/E ratio, SMHX is trading at a significant premium to the S&P500 (P/E=32x).

Risks

The semiconductor sector is trading at a lofty valuation level due to the extremely bullish fundamentals of hyperscalers (and others) spending—in aggregate—$100's of billions of dollars annually on the AI data center buildout. Many analysts say we are in an "AI bubble" that could pop. I don't see that happening any time soon, but that doesn't mean it couldn't or that it one day won't. It could come about via the lack of electrical power capacity, so-called "circular financing" gone awry, or the ROE on AI simply not meeting expectations that eventually lead to a slowdown in new AI data center capacity being built.

My own opinion is that the hyperscalers funding this "hype" are cash-rich and generating tons of free cash flow and are therefore funding their AI capex from the tremendously profitable platforms they are already operating. If you think I am smoking something, I suggest you take a look at Google's (GOOGL) (GOOG) Q3 earnings report. Absolutely fantastic and exactly what I predicted in my recent widely-read Seeking Alpha article, "Google: The AI Leader OpenAI Is Still Chasing (And Will Never Catch)".

My point here is that the so-called "AI hype" has staying power because none of the leading hyperscalers want to stop investing and run the risk of falling behind. META, for instance, is doubling-down on its arguably large AI infrastructure spending. That may be because its CEO Mark Zuckerberg might realize that META's own foundational model (Llama) arguably isn't up to snuff as compared to Google's Gemini+, OpenAI's ChatGPT, or Anthropic's Claude.

Regardless, I think - barring some kind of geopolitical disaster (which is certainly possible these days ...) - we're good-to-go at least thru the end of calendar year 2026. There will certainly be humps-n-bumps along the road, but in my opinion, the AI technology revolution is going to last for the rest of our lives.

Summary & Conclusion

My followers know that I advise investors to build a well-diversified portfolio on the foundation of a high-quality, low-cost S&P500 ETF (like VOO) and to overweight that portfolio with technology stocks. I've written before on Seeking Alpha that the SMH semiconductor ETF should be considered as a core long-term holding in such a portfolio (it is in mine). If you don't already own SMH, you might consider the SMHX instead, or perhaps split your semiconductor allocation between the two ETFs. Heck, I already have a full-position in the SMH ETF, and instead of continually adding to it, I have decided to funnel future semiconductor funds into the SMHX ETF instead.

Now, I know it's hard to invest money at lofty valuation levels. That being the case, I will give the same advice I have been giving with respect to my other primary AI single stock holdings like Google & Broadcom: start by opening a small "starter position" (even if it is only 5 or 10 shares ...) and begin learning about the stock (or fund) by watching how it trades and by reading the quarterly earnings reports and listening to the conference calls. Over time, you will become an expert on the company and/or ETF. Then you will be much better prepared to take advantage of market volatility to add to your position during market sell-offs. Speaking for myself, during times of market turmoil I have always found it easier to add to an existing position as compared to opening a brand new one. Last piece of advice: be patient. It took me over 2 years to build a full position in Broadcom, but it was certainly worth the time and the work.

Bottom line: I like the SMHX ETF and rate it a BUY based on my expectations that we are still in the early innings of what I see as a long-term secular bull market in the technology sector. And within the technology sector, semiconductors are the key to ... well ... everything.

data.title: Why Blackstone Is More Than A Macro Trade
data.description:
Blackstone Inc. (BX) has spent the last five years transforming its core business into a dominant, Fee-Related Earnings (FRE) generating engine. The firm is well positioned for long-term growth beyond the traditional rate-based macro consensus, driven by a structural shift in its business model. While recent investor focus has been on challenges in the firm’s real estate segment, Blackstone's $508 billion Credit & Insurance arm has seen double digit YoY earnings growth and is driving expansion beyond the modest dip in real estate AUM. Loosening credit, pent-up demand, and record levels of institutional dry powder set the stage for a surge in private equity.

Introduction

In 1985, when Pete Peterson and Stephen Schwarzman founded Blackstone, the market was in its "Barbarians at the Gate" era. The founders, two Lehman acolytes, earned a name for themselves by identifying market shifts early and converting them into profitable strategies. Today, Blackstone is the world's largest alternative asset manager, with assets under management (AUM) surpassing $1.2 trillion.

Historically, betting against Blackstone has not been a profitable strategy. The same foresight that has made the firm successful in the past is underpinning their expansion in private credit and insurance. Despite this, many investors incorrectly price Blackstone as a traditional private equity (PE) shop. Unlike some peers that remain vulnerable to market swings and tethered to interest rate fluctuations, Blackstone is now generating the majority of its revenue from recurring fees, a durable and scalable income stream. This pivot from the traditional PE model, expansion in the C&I operation, along with investment in non-REIT related projects, (e.g. infrastructure, and AI), are driving growth.

Expanding A Proven System To Credit And Insurance

Since Blackstone’s 2008 acquisition of GSO Capital Partners, the firm has been building out its credit related investment business. From 2008 to 2020, the subsidiary had grown from around $10 billion in assets to more than $135 billion in assets. In 2023, Blackstone integrated the credit and insurance groups into a streamlined operation.

Today, BXCI (Blackstone Credit and Insurance) represents AUM of over $508 billion, and generated about $36 billion of the $54 billion in total Q3 inflows. By blending multiple verticals, BXCI has become the firm’s fastest growing segment, doubling AUM in the past three years. Due to Blackstone’s sheer size and existing international footprint, BXCI was able to build on an existing infrastructure that peers can’t easily replicate. While most peers rely on smaller networks, and secondary markets, BXCI has a network of over 5,000 issuers, and 550 sponsors.

BXCI’s strength is rooted in its insurance partnerships, including Corebridge Financial, Inc. (CRBG), Legal & General Group Plc (OTCPK:LGGNY) and Everlake (privately held). These relationships provide a steady source of long-term capital, allowing BXCI to invest consistently across different market conditions. By centralizing existing credit and insurance units under one umbrella, the firm is able to offer clients a one-stop solution. The effectiveness of this model is reflected in the numbers.

BXCI has zero realized losses to date and accounted for nearly two-thirds of Q3 inflows to Blackstone this year. BXCI products such as Blackstone Secured Lending Fund (BXSL), and Blackstone Private Credit Fund (BCRED) have consistently outperformed industry benchmarks, such as the Morningstar LSTA US Leveraged Loan Index.

Drypowder And Capital Deployment

Blackstone’s dry powder stores are estimated to be between $188 and $200 billion, nearly double peers KKR & Co. Inc. (KKR) (~$105 billion), Apollo Global Management, Inc. (APO) (~$75 billion), and Carlyle Group Inc. (CG) (~$90 billion). Blackstone represents nearly 10% of dry powder stores across the entire private equity industry, granting them a unique capability to invest in deals that smaller players couldn’t access or afford. Blackstone has focused this capital deployment on high-growth sectors independent of rate cuts. Among these is their investment in AI and digital infrastructure.

Blackstone has positioned itself as a leading investor in the AI revolution, with over $70 billion committed to data centers. The firm is also deploying capital around the margins of this new economy to maximize upside, including energy generation, and cooling systems. Additionally, Blackstone’s expansion in high-growth sectors such as Healthcare, and logistics offers less reliance on their real estate investments. For example, on October 21st, Blackstone announced its $18.3 billion acquisition of Hologic, Inc. (HOLX). This further expansion into healthcare and medical technology was enabled by their access to capital. Hologic’s existing stable cash flow and high-profit margins will be a welcome addition to Blackstone’s balance sheet, and the long-term growth potential of Hologic will be leveraged by increased R&D investment. This summer saw the creation of a dedicated secondaries unit to complement Blackstone’s Strategic Partners group. This will give additional capabilities to this growing part of the business, which just closed a $5.5 billion infrastructure fund. SP Infrastructure IV is the world’s largest dedicated infrastructure secondaries fund designed to capitalize on the growing infrastructure secondary market by providing an avenue for investors to sell or restructure existing infrastructure assets. Infrastructure AUM (industry-wide) is expected to reach $1.8 trillion by 2026, providing a large base for secondary market growth.

Divergence In Valuation

Despite the high-rate environment, Blackstone continues to outperform. In Q3 alone, distributable earnings saw a 48% YoY jump to $1.89 billion. As the private equity space faced years of muted activity in the IPO market, higher interest rates, and a 25% YoY decline in fundraising, Blackstone has managed to thrive, generating $225 billion in total inflows (TTM). To understand the value, it’s key to dig deeper into the stable and recurring revenue streams. Fee-Related Earnings (FRE) are the most reliable tool to measure the underlying business because of their link to AUM. The stability of these revenue streams is a great advantage for Blackstone, offering annuity-like consistency, rather than one-off windfalls. As of last week’s Q3, 2025 release, Blackstone has seen fee-related earnings (FRE) surpass $1.5 billion. Additionally, compared with Apollo (16.7%), Ares (13.4%), and KKR (7.5%), Blackstone has the highest ROE at 26.5%, showing the scalability of their current business model. On the earnings front, Blackstone has diluted EPS growth of 19.5%, and a higher forward dividend yield (3.46%) than Ares (2.98%), Apollo (1.63%), and KKR (0.62%). In price volatility, the 24-month beta (1.43) is below Apollo (1.84), and KKR (1.96). Among major asset managers, Blackstone has managed to maximize ROE, net income margins, and EPS growth.

Risks

Should rate cuts happen at a slower pace, or if inflation flares up, Blackstone (like most of the market) would likely see stock prices stall, and lower than anticipated earnings. Another thing worth watching is BREIT redemptions. While stable at the moment, the housing market pressure persists. Rising competition is also something that warrants caution, especially as peers such as Ares and KKR build up their own C&I operations. Blackstone has the size and diversification working in its favor, but like any company, it’s not immune from market forces, and smaller firms can potentially erode profit margins.

Conclusion

Blackstone has managed to move beyond its early LBO, and M&A shop days, becoming an integrated private equity, credit, insurance, and real estate behemoth. In recent years a pivot away from its traditional revenue model to the current fee-based structure has generated compounding value for clients and shareholders alike. With lower rates expected, BXCI’s AUM growing at 20% YoY, $180+ billion in dry powder ready to deploy, and its leading role in the AI revolution, 2026 brings opportunity for Blackstone to accelerate growth and earnings. Based on these factors, we see Blackstone hitting a price of at least $185 by Q3, 2026, representing upside of around 24% from current levels.

At Avalon Capital Research: we rate Blackstone Inc. a BUY.

data.title: Smurfit Westrock: Market Overreaction And Q3 Resilience (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
With Smurfit Westrock Plc (SW) down ~11% at the time of writing, we see a strong buying opportunity. We anticipated volume pressure after Mondi’s profit warning, and Q3 North American volumes fell 8.7% compared with PKG, which was down by 2.7%. International Paper also reported its numbers with a small volume decline. Given the soft 3Q and the recent share-price slide, a cautious Q4 outlook is largely priced in.

Having said that, we continue to see upside in Smurfit Westrock given a valuation discount, operational synergies with improving margin in North America with restructuring and asset optimization, global footprint to mitigate tariffs, and a potential peace ahead (between Ukraine and Russia) with potentially lower COGS. Additionally, as already reported many times, the company is underpinned by a solid M&A track record and strong execution.

Q3 Results

Smurfit Westrock Q3 sales and adjusted EBITDA reached $8 billion and $1.3 billion, respectively. Top-line sales were up 1% and 4% quarterly and yearly. The company adjusted its EBITDA margin to 16.3% in Q3 (Fig. 1).

Source: Smurfit Westrock Q3 results ppt - Fig 2

On a regional basis, the company's main impact was related to lower volumes in the North American region, while LatAm and the EU were slightly up (Fig. 2). Going to the cash flow, operating cash amounted to $1.13 billion, with FCF at $523 million. FCF was up +70% quarterly. This was backed by a higher working capital release of $171 million, which offset the higher CAPEX. Diluted EPS came in at $0.47, including impairment and restructuring costs of $65 million. This restructuring activity charge was $280 million in Q2.

Fig 3

Our Upside Case

All told, we see this as a market overreaction.

Value Over Volume Strategy Ongoing

Indeed, the company is losing volume in North America, but the market is down by 3-4%. So, Smurfit Westrock attributes 50 basis points of its decline to the value-over-volume strategy. The company is progressing in shutting down production capacity linked to non-performing mills and has already closed three paper mills. Indeed, top management reported: "further reduction in the number of corrugated loss makers and continuing rationalization of inefficient capacity." The adjusted EBITDA margin of 17.2% is a positive sign. More importantly, Smurfit Westrock's adjusted EBITDA accelerated on a quarterly basis, signing a plus +7% versus +3% yearly.

Supportive Synergies Ahead

On a negative note, the company reduced its fiscal year 2025 adjusted EBITDA guidance to $4.9–5.1 billion (compared to a previous indication range of $5-5.2 billion - Fig. 4). This implied an adjusted EBITDA of $1.23 billion in Q4 2025 at the midpoint. Still, the company remains on track to deliver $400 million in synergies. During the analyst's call, top management explained that the cut is related to the weak US demand and higher maintenance ($180-200 million versus last year).

Fig 4

Global Footprint As A Key Differentiator

As a global leader with a footprint in the EU and LatAm, the company benefits from diversification. The company's press release very well supports this: "We believe we are one of the market leaders in EMEA and APAC, where we have once again demonstrated good returns despite a difficult market backdrop to deliver Adjusted EBITDA of $419 million with an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 14.8%." EU mills are operating at a full utilization rate. The company also disclosed its 2026 CAPEX guidance before the year-end. This is unusual, but we see a positive take here. 2026 CAPEX is estimated to be close to consensus guidance at ~$2.4 billion. Still, on a positive note, the company confirmed its quarterly dividend payment of $0.4308 per share (Fig. 5).

Fig 5

Valuation

Here at the Lab, we are deliberately not modeling a volume recovery or improved synergies in 2026. We had previously set 2025 EBITDA at $5 billion, which is now consistent with management’s estimates. We were not insensitive to Mondi's profit warning, so we incorporated short-term challenges, but this share price evolution supports doubling down on our entry price. We apply no change to our EV/EBITDA target multiple (8x), so Smurfit Westrock's enterprise value reached $40 billion. Our EV/EBITDA is below Packaging Corp. of America's and Smurfit Kappa's valuation before the merger with Westrock. Additionally, our target price is below the sector median with a TTM EBITDA of 9.99x (Fig. 6). Considering the current financial obligation, the company's equity value reached $26.5 billion. This represents approximately a 35% upside. There is also a 4.5% dividend yield, which is a total return estimate of almost 40% in one year.

Fig 6

Risks

The company is subject to similar risks as the rest of the paper and packaging sector, such as FX changes (which are relevant given Smurfit Westrock's US industrial footprint and its euro reporting), declining consumer activity given a potential economic slowdown, COGS price changes (raw materials, energy prices, and chemicals), wage inflation, changes in packaging trends, and overcapacity. Supply-demand imbalance is a common downside risk across the sector. Additionally, given the recent merger, Smurfit Westrock is also exposed to integration risks and lower combined synergies. Having said that, the company has a solid track record in M&A.

Conclusion

The Q3 print and call commentary reinforced our positive thesis. We’re surprised by the adverse share reaction and are upgrading Smurfit to a Strong Buy Recommendation. This call is not only based on a discounted valuation, but rather on the best opportunity to invest in what we consider the best-managed company in the paper sector.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.
